1452.content:
Sandy was eighteen this year, and a veritable woman. It didn't matter if she never knew her mother. She practically raised her brothers for the absentee mom. She was used to her position as the only girl in the household, but knew it came with plenty of hardships. Life at school was better for Cassandra Dall. She had decent friends in Lila Torres and Holly Farrell, though both of them were more popular than the obstinate Sandy. She even had a nice boyfriend, Kevin Sharpe: a perfect stooge she could turn loose the minute she desired. He was the only thing in her life she had any control over.

Sandy eagerly waited as her father got home, expecting some sort of attention. It took a good thirty minutes for dad to even notice she was there. He gave a nod in her direction, but no further recognition. It dawned on Sandy very slowly that she wouldn't be celebrating tonight. At least, not at home.

It would be the tenth year in a row now. Ever since the day her mother left them all behind, her father couldn't be expected to remember his shoes in the morning, let alone a birthday cake. It only made things worse when Mitch left for college. And though she knew it would kill him, Sandy couldn't wait to escape this old town, too.

Without notice, Sandy slipped out into the night in the mind to find herself a birthday present. She might as well treat herself if no one else would. After several blocks, she stopped into the local corner shop for her quick fix.

"Hi. How may I help you?"

The cashier spotted her right away. Sandy was surprised by the sudden attention. She approached the counter hesitantly.

"I'm looking for a present."

"Oh? How wonderful! For whom?"

"...Myself. It's my birthday today."

"Well, happy birthday! Isn't it a bit strange to buy yourself a present, however?"

"Yeah, but it's just something I do. So what can you get me for--"

She reached into her pockets, fishing for change. Sandy threw down a few coins.

"All this?"

"You poor girl. You couldn't even get a gumball with what's here. But you know what? Since it's your birthday--"

The man ducked behind the counter, and came up with a strange velvet box. He opened it to an engraved silver coin. A little pregnant woman peeked out at Sandy, smiling on the shiny surface of the coin.

"How about this little beauty?"

Sandy pushed the box away and stepped back.

"I'm sorry, I don't collect coins."

"It's not just any coin, you see. It's special. It can really turn your life around, or so I've heard."

Sandy laughed to herself. What could a coin possibly do to change someone's life? Especially one as dysfunctional as hers?

"I can't possibly afford it."

"It's my gift to you, for your birthday. Didn't I say that?"

"But why would I want--"

"Please, take it. It'll bring you such joy, I'm sure of it."

"It's worthless, isn't it? Are you just trying to get it off your hands?"

"That might be the most valuable object in existence, if what they say about it is true."

"Hmph. And what do they say?"

"I can't remember. All I know is that it's supposed to give you the life you deserve."

"The life I deserve, huh?"

Sandy looked long and hard at the box before making her decision. In a split second, she snatched the silver piece out of the storekeep's hand and held it in her palm. It was a lot heavier than she thought it would be. She turned it over in her hands again and again. The engraving changed expressions from happy to shocked, much to Sandy's amusement. The storekeep's eyes lit up to see Sandy holding his present. She pondered for a few more moments, then decided to keep it.

"I'll take it. Better than nothing."

"Thank you. You won't regret it. And happy birthday!"

"Yeah, thanks."

Sandy walked out of the store and immediately regret filled her. Why in the world did she pick up this strange coin? It's almost as if it enchanted her. But out of the glare of the store lights, it looked entirely worthless. Was it even silver? She stuffed it in her pocket, too proud to return it now. Just then, her phone buzzed. Sandy swiftly opened her phone to find Kevin texting her.

[Hello?]

[Happy birthday, sweets.]

[Thanks, Kev.]

[Hey, whatcha up to?]

[Nothing really. Dad forgot my cake again. Whole b-day thing is kinda lame.]

[Sucks... Wanna come over?]


Normally Sandy didn't seek out Kevin's company, especially at this hour. But she felt compelled to see him tonight. Perhaps he'd make up for the crummy evening she'd been having as of yet. Maybe he'd even gotten her a present.

[Sure. Can you pick me up?]

[Where?]

[Out front of Griger's.]

[You're out there?]
[...]
[I'll be there in 5.]

[K. See you soon ]

She waited maybe two minutes before Kevin pulled up beside her. She got in the rickety old car, and they drove off into the night. Sandy watched out the window for a good long while. Kevin wanted to break the silence, but couldn't find a good reason to. Finally, they were stuck at a stoplight, and Kevin spoke up.

"So, my parents aren't home tonight."

"Yeah?"

Sandy turned with the vaguest interest. Under the orange floodlights of the street, his blonde hair positively shined.

"You wanna hang out there for a while?"

Sandy nodded to avoid catching his eye. She couldn't keep her eyes off his halo of golden hair, however. The longer she stared at him, the brighter the glow. The streetlights danced across his face, played upon his thin white shirt, coursed through the car at blinding speed. He was hurtling towards the suburbs, anticipating something big.

"You wanna slow down there?"

"Oh, sorry. Just thinking about stuff. Y'know."

"Kev..."

They finally stopped in front of the Sharpe residence, and Kevin opened the door for Sandy like a true gentleman. By that time, the orange lights encircling him had driven Sandy crazy. So the moment that door swung wide, she leapt out at her waiting boyfriend and planted a kiss on his lips. He struggled to shut the door while holding her, and she just giggled with delight. At least she'd get something wonderful out of her birthday, now. Maybe that coin was magic, for bringing this spark to her life.

Kevin and Sandy hustled inside. They whooped and hollered as they raced into Kevin's room, excited and playful. She tossed him onto the bed first, then he turned the tables on her and pressed her into his pillows. She laughed at his "suave" attempts.

"You want to keep this going?"

"C'mon, Kev. It's my birthday."

"Well, happy birthday to you, baby."

He kissed her lips hard, then trailed down her neck. Sandy clutched at his back, and closed her eyes with sheer joy. The night lasted practically forever, with both of them hoping it never ended. After a long passionate affair, they both fell asleep.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------- -

In the middle of the night, Sandy woke up. Though she was more than comfortable in Kevin's arms, she wasn't too happy in her rough jeans. She slipped out of the bed and stood up in front of the closet doors. They were mirrored, so Sandy took the chance to straighten herself up. As Sandy removed her pants, she found the coin as it slipped out of her pocket. She remembered the cashier's words, then jokingly flipped the coin.

It came up--
1452.title: Happy Birthday to You!

14521.content:
Sandy looked at the grinning coin, then smiled back at it. She then peered into her reflection for about five minutes, before a strange ill feeling passed over her. She clutched her stomach, and recoiled into a chair. The heady rush of sensations flooding her almost doubled her over. She staggered to her feet, collapsed onto the bed and curled up, trying to focus on something, anything else. She felt completely out of balance. Luckily, her groaning didn't wake Kevin.

She fell back into sleep and counted one, two, three, four, five, six, seven, eight, nine...


--- Day One ---


The morning came without much incident. Sandy woke only two more times that night to go to the bathroom. And though the ill feeling ebbed through the next few hours, it never got as strong as that moment before the mirror. However, that didn't ease her mind. The minute Kevin woke up, Sandy demanded to be taken home. None of the romance from the night before lingered the morning after for her; at least she hoped it was the same on his part. A one time deal, that wouldn't lead to any consequences. He glumly obliged her a ride home, and she spent the rest of the morning in solitude as she dressed for the day.

Of course, this would be the day that she was bloated. Nothing fit the way it used to, making Sandy genuinely worry about herself. What could have caused all this? Was she sick? The reflux in her throat warned her of that truth.

"Great, so this is what I get for my birthday. A little vomit, a heap of regret, and a stupid coin!"

Where was that coin? Had she left it at Kevin's? She dug around in her pockets and eventually pulled it out, still facing her with that same smile. Upon seeing it, she couldn't help but smile a little more. Everything would be okay, as long as she had that coin. It was her lucky charm. And who knows? Maybe it did work a little magic last night. How else would she have been motivated to share the night with Kevin? The farthest they'd ever gone was a little kiss on the cheek, and all of the sudden they were--

A wave of nausea swept Sandy into the bathroom, making her regret her wandering thoughts. She wondered what she could have eaten that would be so violently fighting her. She hadn't eaten anything that whole evening; her dad made sure of that. Maybe that was her problem. She didn't know.

How would she manage the walk to school? Even at the peak of health, it was a staggering walk. In her current condition, it could be horrific. However, the only person who'd be able to drive her would be Kevin, as none of her friends had a car, Dad was at work (and hardly help regardless), and taxis were a joke around this town. It's only a few miles.

Does she chance the hike or call up Kevin?
14521.title: Heads Up

choices: Sandy meets up with her friends.
145212.content:
She had no choice. In her current state, she'd be lucky if she could walk down the hall without keeling over. A three mile jog was out of the question. Though she hated relying on him too much, Sandy knew that she had to ask Kevin for this. She had no doubt he'd be willing to help her, but he'd definitely want to talk about what happened last night. Sandy wasn't sure she knew the answers for herself at this point. Nevertheless, she pulled out her phone and jotted out a quick call for help.

[Kev? I need a ride.]

[Sure thing. I'll be there soon.]

Sandy sighed with relief. No questions asked. It was nice that she could so easily trust him, even if she didn't always want to.

[Love you, sweets.]

Now that was a topic she didn't even want to broach. They hadn't been dating that long, and after one night, he was throwing the word love around? She didn't dare reply back, for fear he'd misunderstand her. Heck, she was misunderstanding herself, after all the bizarre symptoms and peculiar emotional states. What had changed in her from seventeen to eighteen? Did becoming a "true" woman affect her more than she realized? And another thing, why was she asking so many questions of herself?

Sandy sighed and gave up the search for the perfect answer. Her life's complications were no different from any other's, she supposed. So why bother questioning them? She thought back to the blissful woman on the coin. Yes, she could be like that, too. Happy, contented. Pregnant. What a joke! As if that one night could affect her that suddenly.

Kevin honked his horn. Without a second thought, Sandy snatched up her coin and her backpack and headed out. Kevin greeted her with that same smile, and Sandy had to stifle a laugh.

"How're you feeling? Better? You didn't look so good this morning."

"Psh, neither did you. I'm just not a morning person."

Her uncharacteristically cold response chilled Kevin. She held out for a moment, then apologized.

"Sorry. I'm fine, since you were concerned."

"Good to know. I just thought that maybe--"

Sandy cut him off by turning up the radio. Kevin was good at reading subtle hints, so he didn't pry with any more questions. At least until they pulled up to the gates.

Kevin shut off the radio post haste, and turned fully to Sandy.

"Sandy, what happened last night?"

"What do you mean?"

"I mean, do you feel any different?"

"Yeah, I feel a day older. I feel eighteen. So what?"

"No, I mean-- Gah! You're going to think I'm crazy."

"I already do, babe. So what's up?"

"There was this dream I had about us last night."

"Oh?"

Sandy didn't really want to hear it, but kept on listening anyways.

"In the dream, we were- well, you were-- y'know--"

"I really don't."

"Uhm-- you know what we were doing last night?"

And here it comes: the moment Sandy had been dreading. She knew he'd find a way to work it into the conversation somehow.

"What comes after that, y'know. You were--"

"Pregnant, right? You had a dream where I was pregnant."

"Yeah... I thought it was weird. I mean, because you would know or tell me if you were, right?"

"Right..."

Kevin seemed to believe it wasn't a dream. This irked Sandy.

"Sorry, that was odd. Don't think anything of it. I'll see you after school."

"Sure, sure."

"Love you, sweets."

He leaned in to kiss her, but she offered her cheek instead. He was definitely getting too attached to her for his own good. She didn't want to push him further into this fantasy of his. They parted ways with a simple embrace.

"Now to find Lila and Holly. Let's hope Kev didn't talk to them, too."

Her stomach squeezed a bit, forcing Sandy to stop for a moment. The pain had subsided for a bit around Kevin, but the moment he left she was back into her own personal hell. If this continued, she might have to keep him around! The very idea...

She clutched her stomach in pain. This was worse than a period, and she still had no idea what it was. At this point, a trip to the clinic sounded wonderful. Maybe the nurse could find out what was ailing her. But, then again, if she kept her friends waiting, there'd be more problems to worry about. The pain had subsided before, it would subside again.

Should she make a pit stop at the nurse's office to see what's wrong, or meet up with her friends to get her mind off of things?
145212.title: Awkward Post-Discussion

1452121.content:
Sandy walked into the clinic without a care in the world, sure that she'd just come down with something that at worst would get her out of school for a few more days. No complaints there. She knocked on the door, and greeted the lounging nurse with a smile. That smile was quickly replaced by a little more reflux, as Sandy quickly took a seat. The nurse gave her a once over, then returned to her phone.

Sandy waited for the nurse to respond to her presence. Time ticked on, and the nurse seemed not to care. It was as if, in that one look, the nurse had decided Sandy wasn't worth the effort. Angrily, Sandy coughed. The nurse stirred.

"Name?"

"Cassandra Dall."

"Have you missed your period, Cassandra?"

"W-What?"

The nurse shuffled through a desk drawer, pulling out a pamphlet of some sort. Sandy couldn't make it out.

"Simple question: yes or no."

"I-I--"

Sandy drew a blank. She couldn't remember her last period. Did that mean?

"I think so?"

"Hmmph."

The nurse grunted and pushed the pamphlet forward.
Sandy squinted to read the fine print title: Motherhood: A Teen's Guide.

What was this nurse thinking? Just because she missed one period, she was automatically pregnant? This wasn't the first time the subject had come up, either. Was there some conspiracy to make Sandy regret an already awkward night even more? What about that coin that the shopkeep had given her? Wasn't it supposed to give her the life she deserved? She knew she didn't deserve this constant bullying from the universe.

"That's funny, but I'm not pregnant. I think I'm really sick, actually."

"You've been vomiting?"

"Yeah, a lot recently..."

The nurse chuckled, and pushed the pamphlet even closer. Sandy fumed.

"I can't be--"

"That's what they all say. Trust me, I know it when I see it. And I see it all over you."

"But I only did it once, last--"

"Last month, sure. I know. For whatever reason. So now it's up to you to handle it, like a woman."

"It was only yesterda--"

"Yes, I know it was only yesterday you felt like a child. But you're eighteen now, and you're a woman. So act like one, and read the pamphlet! It'll tell you everything you need to know."

"But I'm not pregnant."

"If you don't believe me, go out and buy a testing kit. But you can save yourself a lot of money if you just trust me on this."

"Ugh!"

"Have a nice day, Ms. Dall."

Sandy slammed the door on her way out, blocking out the chuckles inside. Some help the nurse was. Now Sandy had even more problems on her hands. She couldn't get a proper diagnosis from the nurse because, as far as she was concerned, Sandy was one month pregnant. For all Sandy knew, she might be. She couldn't account for all the symptoms any better. But it didn't make sense. She'd never done that sort of thing before, only yesterday. Was it yesterday? Her mind drew a blank.

Sandy looked at the pamphlet in her hands, then wondered whether or not to read it. In her opinion, she might as well know what's not happening to her.

The guide covered the month by month stages of pregnancy, explaining the developments at each stage and offering advice for expectant mothers at each range. It had a paragraph on how to balance school and hospital schedules, fashion tips for managing a changing wardrobe, even a section on how family and friends factor in. The chipper outlook of the booklet cheered Sandy up a bit.

"Well, at least if I am pregnant, I'll know exactly what to do."

She laughed at the notion.

Just then, the minute bell rung, warning all students to hurry to class. Sandy picked herself up and wandered over to first period. She practically slept through the entire morning, no surprise considering how late she'd been up. Lunch brought her to the table with Lila and Holly.

"Sandy, you look a little... I dunno, bleak."

"Something the matter?"

"Oh, it's just---"

Sandy wondered if she should tell the truth to her friends. But did she even know what the truth was? Was she sick? Was she pregnant? And if so, wouldn't they want to know how? It worried her. She considered saying anything.

Does Sandy speak up, or let it slide?
1452121.title: Physician's Opinion

14521211.content:
Even if it was an annoying question, her friends deserved an answer. Otherwise, they might start speculating and escalate the situation out of proportion. But how to word it without inviting further discussion?

"I went to the nurse's office earlier."

"My gosh! Are you alright?"

"I'm fine. It's nothing too serious. She gave me something for it, so--"

"Oh, good!"

"Yeah, for a second there I thought you were gonna drop a bomb on us or something!"

Holly laughed, which unsettled Sandy a bit. Now she worried about what would happen if the true nature of her visit got out. She'd done well avoiding the question for the most part. But any hints towards what really happened and she'd become a laughing stock. Not on her agenda.

"That explains what Kevin was so worried about earlier. I talked with him--"

Here it comes.

"He seemed really worried about you, Sandy. He was blushing bad when we spoke. Did you guys--"

Holly made a lewd gesture, and Lila slapped her for it. Playful Holly recoiled with a grin, but still eyed Sandy for the answer she deserved. Perhaps opening herself up so easily to friends like these wasn't the best choice. Sandy now had to defuse the situation before she ended up discussing her sexual history with the entire cafeteria.

"We just celebrated my birthday together. Nothing you wouldn't do, right, Holly?"

"Pssh... Yeah. There's not much I wouldn't do, however."

She gave Sandy a coquettish smirk, and Sandy rolled her eyes. Leave it to Holly to make a self-deprecating joke all about the other person. Lila spoke up.

"If you two are done making innuendos, I have something to ask Sandy. It's really important."

Holly shared a look with Lila, and the two of them spun on Sandy with big grins. Sandy was afraid for what would come next.

"Since we didn't get a chance to see you yesterday, Holly and I---"

"We planned a big birthday bash this weekend!"

Sandy gasped; half happy, half terrified.The weekend was three days away, and if her symptoms worsened by then, it could be devastating. Not attending a party in her honor was social suicide. But, if she did attend the party, and threw up again, the taunts and jeers following could haunt the rest of her senior year. It would be a tough call, one that she was willing to make to save her skin.

"Holly had her dad rent out the clubhouse. You know the one. Almost never available, any time of year. We were sooo lucky to get it."

"So you're free, right?"

Now how to handle the situation? She couldn't say no to that. It was a once in a lifetime opportunity. The clubhouse was the perfect party location; all of them spoke of going there at least once a week. And now, it was a reality. It just happened to fall right when Sandy was completely overwhelmed.

"And don't worry about asking your dad to take you. Kev says he can get you there."

Just the cherry on top: she'd have to ride up to the party of her dreams with the guy she couldn't handle. The pressure was closing in on her.

"Sounds good. I'll see you there, then."

"8 PM Saturday."

"I'll be there."

Her stomach churned again, forcing her to her feet. If I make it until then, she thought. She made a quick apology, and left her friends for the bathroom. There she stayed until the end of lunch, practically unable to move. Her mind drifted in and out of consciousness. At some point, she had a vision of herself in that closet door mirror again. This time, she was at least four months pregnant. Same as before, Kevin was lying on the bed, and she was examining herself. She ran her hands over the fullness of her body, and eventually found a cold spot. She pulled back her hand to find the coin resting in her palm, that permanent smile still affixed to the woman on the front. She peered deeper and deeper into the mystery woman's expression, until finally, the face started to resemble her own. As she looked back into the closet doors, she was now much further along than before, and still bearing that trademark smile.

She awoke with a jolt at the end of day bell, having lasted the rest of the day without being seen. She snuck out of the school utterly embarassed. Too shy to call up Kevin to give her a ride back home, she used the rest of the walk there to sort out her thoughts. Something was definitely up, and Sandy had the feeling it would only get worse from here on.

As usual, she came home before Bradley and her father. Good. She didn't want them to see her in this state. She laid down on her bed and let her mind wander.
14521211.title: Invitations and Interrogation

145212111.content:
--- Day Two ---


Sandy woke up in the middle of the night yet again, this time with a tenderness all over. Her pajamas definitely weren't fitting like they used to. The pants clung to her hips and strained her gait. Her every step pounded in her head. She had to go to the bathroom yet again. At this rate, alerting the others to her presence was the least of her worries. It was humiliating to be entirely dependent on the nearest restroom. Sandy staggered her way down the hall, too strained to worry about her self-esteem. She shut the door behind her and hung over the sink, panting heavily.

The mirror caught Sandy's eye again. After silently locking the door, Sandy took the chance to examine herself in private. That's when she noticed quite a few changes about herself. Her wider hips stretched her drawstring to the point where she couldn't tie them off anymore. It wasn't just her pajama pants that were ill-fitting, but her nightshirt as well. Her reddish, swollen breasts had pushed their way out under the loose hanging garment. They itched to the touch, so Sandy avoided them as best she could. And though she'd eaten her fair share at lunch and dinner, her waistline would suggest otherwise. She brushed her hands over her slight stomach bulge with morbid curiosity.

Internally, a whole different set of changes were happening. Sandy's emotions flurried into one another as she struggled with a mix of happiness, trepidation, and outright fear. She had no idea what was happening to her, but the thought didn't scare her. A small voice in the back of her mind encouraged her to relax and let "it" happen, whatever it might be. Sandy had no idea what fate she was accepting, but the calming influence of her subconscious kept her from panicking at all these sudden developments.

She returned to bed, eased on by her soothing inner voice. She hoped to get a few more hours sleep before she returned to school the next day. Unfortunately, the churning in her stomach didn't subside for longer than a few minutes at a time. Even with her continued trips up and down the hall, she managed to rest decently.

Morning light streaked through Sandy's window and woke her. She stood up again, pangs still cropping up in her steps. It was much more bearable now, however. Sandy walked into the kitchen to prepare her breakfast. She pondered the pantry's contents, wondering what to eat. The taste for something sickeningly sweet was on her tongue. Bradley wouldn't miss some of his cereal, Sandy rationalized. She poured out a bowl discreetly, ate quickly, then moved on to packing lunch. A good ol' peanut butter sandwich sounded nice, so she brought out the ingredients. Something drove her to pick out the peach preserves from the cabinet as a jelly. Unusual, for a girl who normally didn't like peaches, but even more unusual was her choice of cucumbers as a topping after the fact. Even she eyed her creation with some disbelief, but her stomach didn't lie. It would make a very interesting meal.

Sandy gauged herself before making the journey to school. She knew she had Kevin on hand if worst came to worst, after all. In the end, she opted to walk alone, enjoying the peace of mind it would bring her. She could talk to Kevin later.

She arrived at school with no further delays, a welcome surprise. Sandy found herself among Lila and Holly, then spent the rest of the morning happily chatting with the two of them. They sat in the school's courtyard with their backpacks splayed out. As Sandy went digging for her unfinished homework, Lila raised a question.

"What's that sticking out of your bag, Sandy?"

Sandy glanced down, and saw two papers edging out of her bag. One was the folded up homework paper, and the other was her pregnancy pamphlet. Before she could close the bag, Lila reached out and grabbed one of the two. Sandy squirmed in anticipation, not sure which paper she'd gotten. If it was the wrong one, the consequences could be disastrous. Sandy didn't want to look. Lila let out a little gasp.
145212111.title: Déjà Vu (Day 2)

1452121111.content:
Lila's eyes widened in disbelief. Sandy burned under the heat of jeers surely to come her way. Holly took a quick peek and gasped as well. She peeked out slowly at the paper in her friend's hand.

Fortune smiled on Sandy today, as it was only the assignment for the day in Lila's hands. She took a sigh of relief, then snatched it back from her friend.

"I can't believe you didn't have this homework finished, Sandy!"

"I know, I know. I just wasn't feeling well, you know."

"Yeah, I know. So when's it due?"

Sandy clutched herself instinctually. Could they see it too?

"What do you mean, Holly?"

"The homework, silly. Do you know when it's due?"

Sandy shrugged and played the fool to detract attention.

"Oh heh heh, no I don't..."

"Well, it just so happens to be today, Sandy. How could you forget something this important?"

Lila pierced right through her with a cold gaze. Sandy knew that Lila wouldn't take any excuses, as was her nature. Holly, on the other hand, was much more lenient in regards to schooling. She had already forgiven Sandy for the issue. After all, it wasn't Holly's homework that Sandy would have to copy down.

"I had other things on my plate."

"Like Kevin?"

"Gross, Holly!"

Holly laughed and eased the tension in the air. Lila wouldn't be satisfied with a response like that, but it'd have to do. Class was starting up all too soon.

"I'll see you guys later! Bye!"

"Bye, Sandy!"

"See you in class later."

Lila's biting comment stung Sandy on her way out. In the back of her mind, Sandy worried that Lila might have seen the other pamphlet anyways, and was starting to suspect her. She might be making it worse by playing the fool around her very keen-eyed friend. Sandy considered how she would break the news to her friends if they did find out the truth. Would they even believe her story, about suddenly being pregnant? She hardly believed it herself, and apart from her bizarre morning, she had no real proof that was the case. In time, she'd know for sure.

Like before, the periods passed throughout the day without many notable occurrences. Sandy had to repeatedly use up her hall passes for the bathroom, but she'd gotten accustomed to her frequent trips by now. The teachers didn't care much for her leaving, either. Since it was the second semester of her senior year, most of the hard work was out of the way. Finals wouldn't be for a few more months, and of course prom loomed on the horizon, the perfect distraction. It was surprising to find someone even focused on their studies, like Lila. Everyone else daydreamed about that next big event. Sandy was just taking advantage of a common state of mind.

Then the moment arrived: the class just before lunch. She shared the period with Lila and Holly, and it was their only class together. It was also the class she'd unfortunately forgotten the homework for. As she pulled the packet from her backpack, she realized how many points this assignment cost. It could make or break her grade for the class. Now she knew why Lila made such a fuss over it; Sandy couldn't let this slide like the rest of her life until now.

With the teacher coming around quickly, Sandy had to make a split second decision. Her current options were to turn it in empty or... Or... She struggled to come up with a plan. Just then, the urge to go to the bathroom rose inside her. Sandy realized that she had a way out, or two. Hastily she flipped through the pages of the packet, six in total. It would be tough to finish them in the time it took for her to go to the bathroom, but she could at least edge out a few pages. Then again, if the pressure of that was too much, she could always conveniently find an excuse to visit the nurse. She'd clearly been ill yesterday, so it wasn't much of a stretch to assume she'd be ill today. Hopefully her teacher could connect the dots for her and let her out.

The teacher loomed a desk behind her. It was now or never.

Try to finish the assignment, or skip out to "the nurse's office"?
1452121111.title: Academic Values (D2)

14521211111.content:
Sandy panicked. She turned to her right and gave Lila a quick poke. Lila swiveled in her direction.

"Yeah, Sandy?"

"Please! I need to borrow your homework?"

"Uh uh. Not this time. You're going to take responsibility for this one."

"Please, Lila! I can't fail this class. It would really hurt my grade."

"I'm always the one bailing you out. Do us all a favor and help yourself."

With that, Lila turned her back on her friend and turned in her paper. There went Sandy's first chance. Now all she could do was hope that the assignment was short enough to do in a bathroom break...

Sandy took a deep breath, then leapt to her feet. She flashed her hall pass to the teacher on the way out, hoping that her exit would divert attention from the unfinished packet in her hands. Sandy had a reputation to improve at this school, if she ever hoped to get out of this rut in her road. Plus, the last thing she needed was an F when faced with this mystery sickness. She couldn't keep letting the things in her life slip by her. If she did, she'd be no better than her dad.

Of course, it seems cruel to judge someone while sitting on the toilet, finishing yesterday's homework assignment. Sandy considered the irony for a moment. But there was no more time to lose; she put pen to paper and steadfastly wrote out her answers. Luckily, the problems were at least one word: dates and times. This was especially rare for a history packet. If she'd needed to write out full sentences, she would've been a goner. Everything in her brain started to click into place. It seems fortune was smiling on Sandy again as she finished the assignment in record time. Or what seemed like it.

Sandy re-entered the classroom after a full twenty minutes, as those still awake gave her a glare. She wasn't getting any sympathy from her peers in this circumstance.

Nevertheless, Sandy approached Mrs. Floyd's desk with confidence. The teacher took one look at the hastily scrawled page, then filed it away quietly. Sandy returned to her seat in a state of shock. Normally, Mrs. Floyd would have at least taken this opportunity to teach her some Aesop, or to make an example of her before the whole class. Rarely did any student escape a strict reprimand from her. Unwittingly, Sandy's eyes drifted back to Mrs. Floyd. She gazed at Sandy with this pitying expression, as if to say, "I understand you." Sandy found it odd, as she didn't understand herself what could be the matter. She remembered a similar look from the nurse's office yesterday, when the nurse had declared the impossible. That worried her.

The rest of the lesson droned on. Sandy tried as best as she could not to fall asleep, but something kept drawing her eyes shut. That same fatigue from early this morning cropped again with renewed force. It took all her strength just to keep from drooping into her arms. Lila prodded her awake from the adjacent seat, always glaring. Sandy rubbed her bruised shoulder and returned the look. She wondered how Lila would feel in her shoes.

Each little conflict between Sandy and Lila drew the attention of Mrs. Floyd. Sandy tried to hide her shame with a grin, and Mrs. Floyd obligingly left her alone. Her kind behavior now irked Sandy. She wondered how she could have tamed the lionhearted Mrs. Floyd. And from the looks of it, so was Lila.

Class ended suddenly. Lila packed up her belongings and left without a second glance at Sandy. She knew she'd have to make it up to her friend in the long run, but for now she'd leave Lila alone.

As Sandy gathered her things, she caught the eye of Mrs. Floyd on her. The teacher beckoned her to the front of the room. This didn't look good. Sandy reluctantly walked forward, hoping that this wouldn't be the horrible punishment she'd so far avoided.

"Cassandra--"

Mrs. Floyd was already making it personal. Sandy knew the worst would be coming now.

"Is there something you want to tell me?"

Sandy had diverted her gaze from Mrs. Floyd, expecting a tongue lashing like none other. When she finally looked her teacher in the eyes, she found a very mixed expression. Sandy didn't know how to answer.

"I'm... sorry?"

"It's nothing to be sorry about, Cassandra. I'm sure it's not your fault."

Sandy was a little relieved that Mrs. Floyd didn't care about the homework. Maybe her behavior had made it obvious she wasn't all there. Mrs. Floyd continued.

"I got a call from the front office earlier, namely the clinic. About you."

"Oh?"

Sandy was shocked that the nurse would have called anyone. She'd seemed so lazy yesterday, misdiagnosing her condition and refusing to help her after the fact. So why would she be calling Mrs. Floyd?

"Now I know that it must be tough for you to handle this all on your own. So I want you to know that I'm here for you, if you need help."

"T-Thanks, Mrs. Floyd."

This was extremely bizarre. Mrs. Floyd barely spoke to her students outside of class, and now she was trying to befriend her? It didn't add up. Sandy wanted to interject, when Mrs. Floyd started to speak again.

"I've been there, too, you know. When I was pregnant with my daughter Carol, I was in my first year of college. I was always tired, restless---"

"I think you've got the wrong idea, Mrs. Floyd. I'm not pregnant."

Now Mrs. Floyd was confused. Perhaps Sandy said something she shouldn't have.

"This is just between us, okay? You can be honest with me. I'm not going to judge you. Like I said, I've been in your shoes."

"But I'm not! I can't be!"

"That's what we all say. Sometimes it just happens, completely unexpected. But we're all here to help you."

"Look, that's really nice, Mrs. Floyd. But for the last time, I'm really not pregnant."

Mrs. Floyd sighed, and rolled back in her chair.

"I was just as stubborn as you about it, too. I won't hold you up anymore, Sandy. If you ever want someone to talk to about it, I'm here for you, alright?"

Sandy didn't grace that one with a reply, and walked straight out of the room. First the nurse, and now Mrs. Floyd? Maybe even all her teachers. She'd been wondering why they'd treated her frequent departures with a grain of salt.

Lila and Holly would be waiting for her in the lunchroom. They'd probably find out about the nurse's mistake, too. Would they think the same thing? Did she really seem pregnant? For some reason, she really wished she could smile about all this. But it wouldn't be a laughing matter if people kept confusing her.

Sandy walked into the cafeteria completely perplexed. How would she dispel the rumors about herself if even the teachers believed it? Worse yet, her mystery illness puffed her up to look like a baby carriage. She was even having a hard time believing it was just her body reacting to a nasty flu, and not a body growing inside her. In misery, she took a seat somewhere out of the public eye, deciding to eat alone instead of facing her friends. She pulled out her lunch from earlier, and chowed down. Lucky there was no one to watch her munching on the peanut butter, peach, and cucumber sandwich. It was surprisingly tasty.

But her peace of mind wouldn't last. Someone she knew would have to pass by soon enough, and who else but...?
14521211111.title: Smooth Move (D2)

145212111111.content:
"Sandy?"

A familiar voice called out, one that Sandy wasn't too keen on hearing. Before she had time to turn around, Kevin sat himself beside her.

"I was so worried about you."

He seemed really hurt. Sandy didn't want to see his face like that, so she continued chowing down on her sandwich.

"What are you eating? Is that cucumber?"

"So what if it is? Are you my dad now?"

Sandy retorted vehemently at Kevin, taking him aback. When she finally got a look at his face, she boiled up to see him bearing that same pathetic expression as her teacher. She couldn't stand it.

"I waited outside the school for two hours yesterday, and you never showed up. I thought you'd gotten in trouble, but now I get it. You didn't want to see me."

Exactly, Sandy thought. But she couldn't bring herself to say that to him. He might be a pushover, but she wasn't about to bully him. He was, after all, still looking out for her. She took a breath, then finished off her sandwich. She released the tension in her shoulders, then turned to face Kevin completely. His eyes were filled with so much sadness and worry, like a puppy dog left out in the rain. With a face like that, Sandy couldn't just bark at him.

"Sorry, Kev. I should have told you."

"At least text me next time if you're not going to be there. So I know you're okay."

"I will."

"If anything were to happen to you, I don't know what I'd do."

"You don't have to get so worked up about me, Kev. I can handle myself."

"I just care about you, a lot."

"Thanks for caring."

His glance shifted downwards.

"Do you care about me still?"

"Of course I do, silly! What makes you say that?"

Kevin drew closer to Sandy, making her blush. Suddenly, he embraced her. His tight grasp, his blond curls brushing against the back of her neck, his soft little breaths all brought back the memories of two nights ago. Deep down, she knew she adored him. That night was proof enough in her mind. Her moods were just muddled by the onset of her illness, this pregnancy scare, and probably crazy hormones. She didn't know if she was ready to call it love, however, so she played her cards close to the chest. In time, who knows? Maybe things would change between them if she opened up more, but that would take a lot of time and a lot of trust. They'd only been dating a few months, hardly enough time to really get to know the whole person.

Kevin drew back with a slight smile on his face. He apparently remembered something funny, which brought the light back into his eyes and the laugh back into his lips. Sandy couldn't help but smile back.

"So I imagine you've heard about the party by now?"

"Sure have. You still want to drive me?"

"Sure do."

Sandy was looking forward to the drive after all. It meant more time getting to know Kevin, which, in the end, she really wanted to do.

"I'll be looking forward to it, then."

"Me too."

The two of them spent the rest of lunch chatting aimlessly about other things. Nothing too important, which was good for Sandy. She needed someone to get her mind off the past few days, and ironically Kevin handled the job perfectly. He didn't press her any further on the sandwich, too, which was a plus. By the time lunch was over, both of them felt significantly more relaxed. They rose to their feet together. Kevin put his hand on Sandy's shoulder.

"Goodbye, sweets."

He then planted a kiss on her cheek.

"I'll text you later, Kev."

"Okay. See you around."

The two of them set off for opposite sides of the campus. That was another snag in their relationship: no shared classes. Most of their time together was spent out of school. Not that Sandy minded, for Kevin also made a nice distraction from her other big problem at home. But, it would be nice to share a few periods of the day.

Sandy mulled her way through the rest of school without much event. Like in Mrs. Floyd, none of her teachers bothered her when she frequented the restroom. She wondered if she could use this to her advantage, but didn't linger on the thought.

The day ended and Sandy headed for the usual exit. On her way there, she ran into Holly, walking all by herself. Her friend looked a little bummed, so she stopped by to talk to her.

"Hey sexy, what's up?"

"Oh, Sandy, it's you. Didn't see you at lunch, thought you'd gone home."

"Nah, I was here. Just had lunch with Kev."

"Ooh."

Holly gave a playful roll of the eyes, but didn't cheer up much. Sandy pressed on.

"You okay, Holly?"

"Yeah, it's just the usual slew of problems. Cheer squad practice being cancelled for the third time this week, and, well, Seth."

"Seth, again?"

"Yeaaah..."

Seth Hastings was Holly's on-again off-again boyfriend, and a constant troublemaker. Before her, he'd been rumored to date entire girls' teams, namely soccer, lacrosse, water polo, even debate and chess. Once he made his way to the senior cheerleaders, however, he was stopped dead in his tracks by Holly. They'd since dated for months or weeks at a time, but since old habits die hard, they'd end up breaking it off every so often. Not to say Holly herself didn't sometimes seek out other guys; she had a bit of a reputation herself. Yet, something always drew them back together, and Sandy never quite understood what.

It seemed as if this was one of those break-up periods.

"I don't know what his problem is anymore! "

"You should know Seth, it's in his nature to fool around."

"It's not fooling around anymore, Sandy. He just--- he wants to get serious with me."

"Get serious? He's one to talk."

"That's what I said. But then he was all, 'We need to take this relationship to the next level.' And I didn't know what to say. I thought we were already pretty intimate. What's the next step beyond that?"

"Well, you guys have been on and off for quite a while now."

"It's just how we are. I thought he understood that."

"Holly, do you even understand that? I mean, if you don't want to be with him--"

"But I do, Sandy, I really do! I just don't know if I can do what he's asking."

"It's not like he's asking you to marry him, Holly. Lighten up."

Holly shot Sandy a bitter look. Sandy knew something was up now; Holly never took matters this seriously. Something Seth said must have really struck a chord with her.

"Hey, we've still got the party this weekend. So if he's still bugging you, think of all the fun you can have without him."

"Eh, you're right, Sandy. Thanks a bunch."

Holly hugged her friend quickly before setting off in the other direction.

"Bye now! See you tomorrow!"

"See ya, Holly!"

Sandy now stood before the exit, ready to walk home. She took her first few steps with a clearer mind, then immediately backtracked to the nearest restrooms for a quick pit stop. This condition was really taking it out of her...
145212111111.title: Left in the Dust (D2)

1452121111111.content:
Sandy walked in the door to find Bradley splayed out in front of the TV. He was hacking away at some monsters on his favorite video game. Sandy had to laugh at the sight of her ten-year-old brother curled up in a pillow fort, his eyes glued to the screen. Just to mess with him, Sandy stepped right in the way when Bradley laid out his killshot. After a few seconds of dazed confusion, Bradley leapt to his feet and threw down the controller.

"No fair! I almost beat him, and you messed me up!"

"Hello to you, too, Braddles."

"Grrrrrrr..."

The only thing Bradley hated more than people interrupting his game were stupid nicknames. Sandy made a point to come up with a new one every time she saw him.

"You can always try again, right?"

"I didn't save!"

"Ah, then maybe I taught you a lesson, huh?"

"Hmph!"

Bradley sat back on the couch with his arms crossed. He turned away with a pout, causing Sandy to laugh even harder at him. Even though he could be a little brat, she didn't mind. Sandy actually liked children. When she started high school, she'd considered becoming a pediatrician, or even a teacher. When Bradley was a little younger, she babysat him and his friends on the weekends. So she'd grown up very fond of children, dreaming of having her own in the far off future. In the present, she still had to take care of Bradley, who'd grown out of the cute kid phase about a year ago.

"You're making dinner tonight, Sandy. Dad called and said he won't be home until late."

"Then you're going to help me, little brother. It's about time you learned something useful."

"But I'm playing my game! I have to get back to Level 90."

"It'll be waiting for you, if you save it."

Bradley huffed and puffed for a bit.

"If you help, we'll go out for ice cream after dinner."

He jumped right up at the mention of a reward.

"Okay!"

The rest of the afternoon went by pretty quickly. Sandy made sure to check for her homework this time, and finished a few lingering assignments she'd left over. Sandy actually got Bradley to clean his room up, too, with the same promise of ice cream. When they finally got to making the pizza bread for dinner, Bradley was so well behaved Sandy practically didn't know him. It made her fond of the days when they'd been so close. It was a pity he was doing it all for some cheap ice cream. True to her word, she bought him a tiny portion cup of ice cream. For herself, she snuck a whole pint into the cart. As long as Bradley didn't see...

Some time later, Sandy put the ten year old to bed after a quick game session that evening. Once he was safely asleep, she took out the pint container and sat down to watch some TV. She fell asleep on the couch with the empty pint sitting on the counter.
1452121111111.title: Babysitting the Brother (D2)

14521211111111.content:
--- Day Three ---


For the first time in two days, Sandy awoke from a restful night's sleep. Funny, considering it had been on her couch. She raised her arms up high and stretched. There was a twinge of pain in her lower back, but nothing she didn't expect from her bizarre sleeping posture. Sandy calmly walked into her room to pick up some clothes for the day. As she gathered her things, she noticed a pile of her clothes from the other day in a wad in the corner. She thought back to the coin, which she hadn't seen since her birthday. She almost went looking for it, before hearing Bradley stirring in the other room. If she wanted the bathroom to herself, she'd have to be quick about it.

Sandy swept up her clothes with one arm and a towel with the other. Quickly she darted down the hall, locking herself into the bathroom. She reached around for the lights, then set her clothes on the counter. After a moment's pause, she stepped into the shower and washed away her troubles. Everything was going swimmingly, as if she was perfectly healthy again! But it was too good to be true, for just as she stepped out, she ducked headfirst into the toilet and vomited. She lost her footing after that, falling to the ground and staying there for a good five minutes. Once she regained awareness, she stood up before the mirror and tried to resume getting dressed. However, other issues stood out for her.

Sandy slid into her underwear fairly easy, but when trying to blindly clasp her bra, she ran into a bit of difficulty. Her eyes flicked up to the mirror, where she caught a glimpse of something she definitely hadn't expected. Sandy jumped back in shock, sending the bra flying to the ground. In her reflection there were now two sizable spheres with dark, saucer-like circles in the middle. She poked one of them, cringing at its tenderness. She feebly lifted the bra to her chest, comparing the two. No wonder her bra wouldn't fit, she'd now swollen up at least a cup size!

There was no explanation in Sandy's mind that could explain this sudden development. She'd stopped growing years ago, so there should be no reason for her breasts to start ballooning like this. Unless there was some truth to the nurse's statement...

Taking a peek out the door, Sandy couldn't see Bradley down the hall. Good. She snuck back into her room, clothes in hand. Safely behind the confines of her own walls, she sat down and thought about what to do next. Just then, she saw the clock on the wall. It was actually two hours before school! Nicole gasped as she felt a sudden warmth bloom from deep inside of her. A strange tingling sensation started to dance across the skin of her impossibly flat stomach, and a foggy sensation began to creep into Nicole's mind. Nicole staggered, and held her hand against the wall to steady herself. Reality rapidly re-wrote itself and new memories began to replace Nicole's old ones. The last eight months of her life was partially erased and re-written, and Nicole's mind suddenly filled with memories that hadn't been there just moments before.

The memory of having sex with that cute, dark haired guy she met at Chloe's beach party. Nicole could remember lying on the cool sand, his warm body writhing on top of her, his lightly calloused hands skimming over her soft skin. She could remember how oddly gentle he was, through the drunken haze, and how he had kissed her face over and over again as he pushed himself into her. She could remember them laughing about how sand had gotten everywhere, she could remember the dark haired guy pulling her up to her feet, and she could remember leaning against him as he led her back over to where the rest of the party had gathered around an enormous bonfire.

Nicole remained frozen in place as memories flickered through her mind. Slowly, her stomach began to grow. It pushed out slowly into a slight curve, making it look as if Nicole was simply pushing her stomach out. It continued to steadily swell, rounding out into a potbelly that stuck out proudly from Nicole's otherwise slender frame. Her breasts grew a little fuller and started to push against her suddenly too-small bra, tanned flesh threatening to spill over the tops of the cups.

Nicole could remember being sick, sick enough that she had to force herself to go see a doctor. Her family's private doctor, to be precise. There he had bluntly told her to take a pregnancy test, and then had informed her that she was expecting. He hadn't seemed surprised, he knew what sort of life the party princess led, and he had simply given her the information on what to do from there on out. Nicole had stamped her foot and demanded an abortion, the doctor had informed her she was too far gone. She might of had all of the money in the world, but no surgeon in the world would abort a pregnancy that advanced.

Nicole's stomach bloomed out into a firm baby bump, a taut ball that jutted out over the waistband of her unbuttoned denim shorts. It began to hang down a little from the weight and pulled at the small of Nicole's back. Her bellybutton popped as her belly surged outwards without warning. Her breasts swelled up another cup size, pushing against the thinning material of Nicole's now too small tank top. The growth began to slow, ever so slightly, as Nicole's pregnancy approached eight months. Her bump was a little on the larger size, she couldn't pull down her tank top over the expanded flesh if she wanted to,and her skin was as taut as a drum.

"What did you say, Betty?" Nicole blinked at her friend as the last of her memories were slotted into place, "I didn't hear you."

"Excuse me?" said Nicole, unable to believe what she just heard.

"You heard me, Nicki. F-A-T, fat. That's what you've become," replied Betty in a mocking tone.

Nicole fumed. Ever since she'd found out she was pregnant, Betty had been completely unsupportive. Admittedly, no one she knew was really happy that she was now with child, herself included, but they'd all eventually learned to deal with it. Betty, on the other hand, seemed to think that making fun of her was now part of her duties as her best friend.

"It's not like I'm fat for no good reason," she explained for what had to be the tenth time in the last month. "I'm pregnant. This," she gestured to her larger frame, "is part of the package."

"That may be so. But that doesn't change the fact that you are a tubbo now."

Nicole scowled and crossed her arms, resting them on top of her bared belly. It wouldn't be so bad if she was just giving her some light-hearted teasing. Friends do that kind of thing all the time. But Betty was being downright mean! She knew Nicole was going through a hard time, and she was insisting on making it harder. She hadn't really been preparing for the birth that would be coming in about a month's time. She hadn't gotten any baby supplies or maternity clothes or anything like that. Part of her had been trying to deny that this was actually happening to her. And deep down inside her, she got a bit of a thrill showing off how large she was getting. She liked baring her belly to the world. But she wasn't about to admit that to anyone, even herself. 'Still,' she thought to herself, 'I should get some baby supplies. I've been putting it off way too long.' "You don't understand what I'm going through," she said out loud.

145331112212.content:
Nicole watched in fascination as Betty began to blur and change. Her belly and chest began to swell, until she there were as large as Nicole's. Additional weight appeared on other parts of her body. At the same time, Betty's clothes began to blur and change, becoming stylish but sensible maternity clothes. To Nicole's further astonishment, her own clothes changed, as well, until she was now dressed in maternity clothes, as well.

A new set of memories began to flood into Nicole's mind. Both she and Betty had gotten drunk and then pregnant at Chloe's beach party, each of a result of one-night stands with guys they didn't even know. Nicole had gone into deep denial about her pregnancy, until Betty had snapped her out of it, dragging her along to buy maternity clothes and baby supplies. It was largely thanks to Betty and her mom that one room in Nicole's condo was now set up as a nursery. They still quarreled a lot, but they were united by the shared shame dumped on them by their family and "friends" who derided them as the two "loose" girls who'd carelessly gotten pregnant.

"My God", thought Nicole, "Did the coin do that?"

Aloud, she replied to her friend's last remark.

"Tubby'? 'Tubby' yourself, fatass!"

Betty frowned, and then smiled ruefully.

"Yeah, you're right, Nicki, I'm no better than you. God, I'm going to have to live in the gym to shed all the weight I've gained from this kid. Anyway, is your mom still not speaking to you?"

"No", said Nicole. "She still hasn't forgiven me for sullying the family name - and for doing something so 'common'. She's as mad now as when I first told her. I think Daddy would like to come around, but he's too afraid of her."

"So, they've completely cut you off?"

"Yup. Thank God my condo and car are completely paid for. Plus, my Great-Uncle Horace left me a fair-sized chunk of money. If I spend it carefully, I can live fairly comfortably off it at least until young Offspring starts grade school, but there won't be any more trips to the Caribbean for me anytime soon. If my parents haven't come around by then, I'll probably get some kind of a part-time job to have some money coming in, to supplement my cash supply. Not that I'm qualified for much. You're lucky - your parents haven't shut you off."

Betty smiled at that. "That's not how my Mom operates. Yeah, she's as supportive as can be, but it's all so she can have me where she can remind me how disappointed in me she is. There are times when I wish she wasn't speaking to me. God knows how Daddy would've reacted, if her were still alive." Betty's father had passed away of cancer when she was quite young.

Nicole replied,. "Well, your Mom has helped me a lot, too. If she likes, she can disapprove of me sometimes to take the heat off of you a bit."

Betty laughed at that, and Nicole joined her.

Betty became more serious. "To be honest, Nicki, I was kind of surprised that you didn't have this kid, well ' taken care of', you know?"

"I waited too long", said Nicole. "I was in total denial for months. By the time I got off my butt and went to the doctor, it was too late. I was too far along. How about you? Did you ever think about it?"

"Not really", said Betty. "You know my family's Catholic. I don't take it very seriously, but my Mom does. She would have made your Mom look mild by comparison if I'd'v'e even said the word 'abortion' in front of her. Anyway, Nicki, did you ever think about giving the kid up for adoption."

"No. It's funny - I didn't want a kid right now. I didn't plan for it, and God knows what kind of a train wreck I'll be as a mom, but if I'm going to have this kid, I'm going to keep it."

"Ah, well", said Betty. "I gotta pee."

"Me, too" , said Nicole.

"Thank God this place has two toilets" said Betty, pulling out an ancient silver dollar that had belonged to her great-grandfather. "Call it."

"Heads", said Nicole.

Betty flipped the coin. "Nertz" she said, "Heads, it is. OK, you can use the one on this floor, I'll drag my bloated carcass upstairs.."

Nicole used the trip to the toilet to think about what had happened. she had flipped the coin and Betty had become pregnant. Time had been re-written and Betty didn't seem to have even. noticed, whereas she seemed to have two sets of memories in her head, although the new memories were somehow clearer, more "real". A thought struck her.

"Wait a minute! If the coin had made Betty pregnant, did it somehow make me pregnant, too?"

Yes! If she strained her mind really hard, she could pull up a third set of memories, now almost buried. When she had found the coin, she hadn't been pregnant! It was only when she flipped it the first time and looked at herself in the mirror that it had happened! Just her luck that she found this crazy thing! Still, now that she had it, she had to figure out the best way to use it.

When she came out of the bathroom, she heard Betty call her out to the kitchen.

"I'm having a sandwich. You may as well come out here and get fatter with me!"

As the two friends sat down to eat, they heard someone coming it the condo's front door.

"That'll be Mom," said Betty. "She said she might stop by. WE'RE IN THE KITCHEN,MOM!"

Betty's mother, Bridget O'Donnell, came into the kitchen, bearing a sack of groceries. She'd had Betty quite young, so she was still in her early forties. She strongly resembled her daughter, and was still in good condition, and quite attractive for her age.

"Hello, my two fallen angels", she said, hugging and kissing first Betty and then Nicole. "I brought a few things for you."

"Aw, Mom", you didn't need to do that", said Betty.

"It's my pleasure, dear", said her mother. "Someone has to look after you girls." She gave her daughter a half-humorous look. "Hopefully, you can do a better job bringing up your children than I did mine."

"Mo-om", said Betty, rolling her eyes.

Bridget smiled, and then took on a serious look.

"I was only twenty when I got pregnant with you, dear - just a kid. I really wasn't prepared to be a mother yet, that's why I worry about you two. I sometimes think that if only I could have a baby now, I'd finally be mature enough to take care of one."

"It's not too late, Mom, you're not so old", said Betty. Bridget had never dated after her husband died, even when Betty had encouraged her to do so.

"Thank you, dear" said Bridget, "but I think I am. It's a shame, though. I think I might finally be good at it."

Nicole grasped the coin in her hand, and thought about it. Should she do it? Should she give Bridget her chance to be a "mature" mom?

However, the next morning, she had had a huge, flaming row with him, followed by a fairly irrevocable break-up. When her parents had been informed of her pregnancy, they had disowned her, and the ex-boyfriend had made himself scarce, refusing to take responsibility. She had been taken in by an aunt who had apparently had a similar event in her past, and who was therefore sympathetic. Chloe had recently been reconciled with her parents after a fashion, but she was still staying with her aunt. As a result of her altered history, Chloe was now somewhat less antagonistic to the others, owing to their shared predicament.

Nicole sat quietly as Chloe, Betty and Sylvia more or less amiably discussed their philosophies of baby care. Occasionally, she would put a word in, but she was in fact mulling over two competing ideas that were bouncing around in her head.

One was to seek out as many other girls that had been at the beach party as she could and use the coin to make them pregnant as well. It had caused quite a stir in her little circle when four of the girls had become pregnant, what if she could manage eight, or a dozen,or more?

The other was that she had begun to use the coin compulsively, and was starting to worry if it was having a bad effect on her. She remembered an anime she'd seen once about a samurai who'd had a cursed sword. It helped him win every battle, but with each victory it had eaten away at his soul, until finally the sword was using the samurai instead of the samurai using the sword. Was the coin beginning to use her?

Nicole and Betty eventually took their leave of Sylvia and Chloe, and continued on their walk through the park.

"You know", said Betty, "I'm still hungry. Let's go get some more food."

"OK", said Nicole. "Where do you want to go?"

"Schmidt's Cafe is just on the other side of the park", said Betty. "They do awesome desserts."

"Alright", said Nicole. "Shame we can't have some wine. I could really use a drink."

Betty glared at her.

"Oh, don't worry", said Nicole, defensively. "Even I'm not that irresponsible."

The two friends made their way to Schmidt's and were seated immediately.

"Urp", said Betty. "I gotta go to the ladies' room."

"Maybe, and no", said Betty. "I should be OK. If the waitress comes while I'm away, order me the Double Deluxe German Chocolate Cake à la mode, with whipped cream, and a root beer float."

"Wow", said Nicole. "That order alone would've made Sylvia's head explode."

"Then it's a shame she didn't hear it", said Betty. "I'll be back as soon as I can."

The waitress came right after Betty left. Nicole placed her friend's order, and ordered a banana split and a chocolate milkshake for herself.

While she was waiting, she looked at the table next to theirs. Two identical twin sisters were sitting there, both wearing sweatshirts with the logo of Hollenpforte University - a local school - on them. They had dark hair done up in ponytails and looked to be about eighteen. Nicole got the vibe of out-of-town kids enjoying their first taste of being away from home and being out from under the parental thumb for the first time.

Nicole eavesdropped on their conversation. Apparently, they were called Cheryl and Beryl, for which Nicole thought that they ought to sue their parents.

"Remember, Cheryl", said Beryl, "this is the first time Mom's seen us since we came down here. We need to impress her with how responsible we've been."

"I know, I know", said Cheryl. "God, you're as bad as she is for nagging!"

"Well, you know hyper-protective she's been since Dad died. It took too much effort just to get her to let us to leave home and come here!", said Beryl.

"We're both eighteen", said Cheryl. "I don't see why we'd have to come running just because she says so."

"Because she controls the purse strings, that's why", said Beryl. "Until we have money of our own, we have to dance to her tune."

Nicole felt an urge to mess with them. She looked at Cheryl, and flipped the coin.

1453311122121122111111212123.content:
Nicole would have been happy to chat with Betty, but her friend seemed unable to divert herself form inhaling her dessert, so Nicole did likewise while still listening to the twin and their mother.

"OK, Mom", said Beryl. "You've heard our story, now let's hear yours."

"I guess it's only fair", replied her mother. "The truth is, I was lonely without you two around, so I decided it was time for me to start having a social life again. So, I actually went to Jill and Harry Oakes' annual party, instead of blowing it off, the way I usually did after your father died."

She paused to sip her coffee.

"Anyway, I was so nervous at being around people again, well, I had a few martinis."

"'A few'?", asked Beryl.

"Well, eight", said their mother. "Eight that I recall, anyway."

"Oh, no...". said Cheryl.

"Anyhow, I got to talking with this man I met there. An older man, but, the rugged, outdoorsy type. He reminded me a bit of your father, you know, and he suggested we go outside for some fresh air, and I said 'sure'. and we went out to that cabana the Oakes' have in back of their pool, and..."

"Oh. Emm. Gee", said Cheryl.

"Well", their mother continued, "he'd grabbed a bottle of wine, and we shared it, and then, that'?"well, one thing led to another..Look, do you really want details of what happened next?"

"No", said Beryl, in a small voice.

"Anyway", their mother continued. "I woke up the next morning in one of the Oakes' guest rooms, wearing the dress I'd had on the night before. Someone had left my shoes outside the bedroom door. I never did find my underwear..."

"Please stop", begged Cheryl, tearfully.

"I had splinters in my bottom from the wooden floor of the cabana..."

"TMI, Mom, Tee. Emm. Aye!", said Beryl. "I just can't believe it."

"Why, girls", said their mother. "I didn't do anything you two didn't do."

"Yeah, but you're our mother", said Cheryl. "We don't like to think about you being skanky! Would you wanna hear about Grandma whoring it up?"

"Ewwww", said their mother. "I see your point."

"I don't suppose this guy has a name?", asked Beryl.

"Oh, I imagine he does", replied their mother. "I'm not quite sure what it is though. Bill? George? Steve? Something like that, anyway."

"'Something like that'?", said Cheryl.

"Anyway", their mother continued, "I got out of there as quickly as I politely could. I vaguely apologized to Jill, hoped that I hadn't been too much trouble. I still have no idea what, if anything, she knows about what went on. I haven't had the nerve to face her since. Go,d when people hear I'm pregnant, what will they think of me?"

"Well, we're all in the same boat, Mom", said Beryl.

"Say,Mom" , said Cheryl. "I don't suppose you've heard from the father since then?"

"No", said their mother. "To be honest, I'm not entirely sure that he knows my name, anymore than I know his. Frankly, I'm not at all sure that I want to see him again."

"I guess I your point", said Beryl.

"Anyway, girls", said their mother, "We have to make some hard decisions now about what we're going to do next."

At that moment, Nicole was distracted by the arrival of their waitress, who was asking if they were all set.

"I'm good", said Betty. how about you, Nic?"

"I'm all set", said Nicole. "Lett us have the check, please."

And here is something for you, she thought. Shed gotten good at flipping the coin surreptitiously.

She head the words REALITY CHANGE!, and the waitress' belly expanded until it looked almost as big as Nicole and Betty's own.

"So, when are you due?", asked Betty.

"About another two-and a half months", the waitress replied. "And you?"

"We've got another month, maybe a month-and-a-half", said Betty.

"Well, good luck", said the waitress.

"You, too", said Betty.

As you got up to leave, Nicole caught the twins' mother's eye, patted her enormous belly, gave her best smile, and siad, "We got drunk at a party, too!"

"Come on, Nicole", said Betty, pulling her friend away by her arm.

"Where to next?", said Nicole.

"Can we go back to your place?", asked Betty. "It's nearer, and my dogs are barking."

"Sure thing, hon", said Nicole.

As they headed back to her condo, Nicole wondered if she should tell Betty about the coin, and her plans for it. On the one hand, Betty would go ballistic when she learned what Nicole had done to her. On the other hand, once she'd gotten over being angry, Betty might just like Nicole's plan. Her sense of humor was just as twisted as Nicole's, and she might just enter into the plan wholeheartedly. It would be nice to have an accomplice!
